messageBody:
There is one thing that I never quite got the lightbulb on in the desire to make all things public or an interface. What if I have a class that has a small section of code that is repeated constantly in the class. The way I was taught back in the day was to pull that section code out and make it a private member to enhance code readability and security (singular updates).
This code snipped is not really suitable for an interface. Likewise it should not be made a public class simply because it is only a bit of code reduction. We have a section of code that assembles a filepath string based upon some parameters given and its own given values. Its not a big method, but it does a bit of simple logic and string concats. However, we put it in its own method so that when changes occur (and they have over time) that we only need to update one spot; thus avoiding the problems with changes not being carried through to all applicable sections.


class foo {

public method_1(String param1) {
// some tasks
String value = repeatMethod(newVari);
// some tasks
}

public method_2(String param1) {
// some tasks
String value = repeatMethod(newVari);
// some tasks }

...<snip>...

public method_n(String param1) {
// some tasks
String value = repeatMethod(newVari);
// some tasks
}

private String repeatMethod(String newVari) {
// some tasks
return anotherVari;
}


}

The usual assumption is that you're testing code you can change, so the
usual advice will be to change to code to make it easier to test.

Ask the developers what their concern is about client code being able to
access their classes. Maybe they have nothing to worry about. Beyond
that, they ought to consider using Interface Segregation instead of the
dreaded visibility keywords.

If the class is package-visible, then placing the tests in the same
package -- even if in a different source tree -- will do. It's not my
favorite solution, but it will do.
